Building.value: Mosteiro de Santa Maria da Vitória (Batalha Monastery)

Current state of conservation.value: 1996: The panel was taken down and kept in storage.                                                                      2008: Superficial cleaning was carried out, using distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs. Paint was locally consolidated with Plexigum N80 in acetone [8%]. A repair lead calm was removed and the glass fragments were bound using Paraloid B72 in acetone [70%]. Peripheral U-shaped lead-antimony (98:2) calms were applied and locally soldered to the panel. Some solder points were reinforced and lead calm cracks were soldered.The panel was kept in storage. Conservator: Pedro Redol.                              2012: The panel was put on display at the Batalha Monastery's interpretation centre, inside a climatized showcase (RH 60%, 18 °C).

Description.value: A standing, bearded shepherd, wearing a cloak and a hat, looks up in awe while praying. In front of him, two sheep are to be seen in the middle of the bush. A reused piece shows the arm of another praying shepherd.

Dc:source.value: BARROS, Carlos Vitorino da Silva O vitral em Portugal, séculos XV e XVI. Corpus Vitrearum Portugal, I. Lisboa: Comissariado para a XVII Exposição de Arte, Ciência e Cultura do Conselho da Europa, 1983. HESS, Daniel - In search of Luís Alemão: stained glass in Germany from 1400 till 1460. In REDOL, Pedro (coord.) - O vitral: história, conservação e restauro. Lisboa: Instituto Português do Património Arquitectónico, 2000, p. 44-53. REDOL, Pedro - O Mosteiro da Batalha e o vitral em Portugal nos séculos XV e XVI. Batalha: Câmara Municipal da Batalha, 2003.

Iconclass keywords.value: Annunciation of Christ's birth to the shepherds at night.

Images descriptions.value: A standing, bearded shepherd, wearing a cloak and a hat, looks up in awe while praying. In front of him, two sheep are to be seen in the middle of the bush. A reused piece shows the arm of another praying shepherd.

Production technique and style.value: Leaded panels made of colourless, bulk coloured and flashed glass, painted with grisaille. Painting style of Luís Alemão's successors in Batalha.

Building.value: Mosteiro de Santa Maria da Vitória (Batalha Monastery)

Current state of conservation.value: 2006-2007: All the panels were taken down, flattened, and cleaned (distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs). Grisaille painting was pre-fixed and fixed where necessary (Paraloid B72 in acetone [8%]). Glass fragments were bound with Paraloid B72 in acetone (60%)and small gaps filled in with fired painted glass, Iron tie bars directly soldered onto the panel were unsoldered and removed, and copper ties soldered instead. Tinted glazier's putty was locally applied in order to streghten and waterproof the panel. Reinstalled using new brass tie bars, lime-based mortar (sides and bottom) and glazier's putty (top, along saddle bar above). Company: IN SITU. Conservator: Raquel Fonseca dos Santos.

Description.value: Standing and kneeling in front of the Virgin Mary,the three biblical kings adore the Christ Child and make their offerings.

Current state of conservation.value: 1996: The panel was taken down. Conservator: Rita Isabel Freitas Vicente.                                1998: Loose putty was removed. Biocidal treatment (folmaldehyde aqueous solution [0,1%]) and superficial cleaning (distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs) were carried out and unstable paint was locally consolidated  (Paraloid B72 in butyl acetate [3%])Peripheral U-shaped lead-antimony (98:2) calms were apllied and locally soldered to the panel. Some solder points were reinforced. Repair lead calms were removed and the glass fragments were bound using Araldite 2020. Small gaps were filled in using Araldite 2020 and cold painted (with acrylic paints Pébeo and grisaille). Tinted glazier's putty was locally applied in order to streghten the panel. The panel was kept in storage. Conservator: Rita Isabel Freitas Vicente.                                                                      2012: The panel was put on display at the Batalha Monastery's interpretation centre, inside a climatized showcase (RH 60%, 18 °C).

Description.value: The bust of Christ with praying hands and traces of a garment is depicted. Water is poured onto Him from a jug, hold by a hand in the upper right corner. The Holy Ghost as dove descends from the upper left corner.

Lisboa: Comissariado para a XVII Exposição de Arte, Ciência e Cultura do Conselho da Europa, 1983. HESS, Daniel - In search of Luís Alemão: stained glass in Germany from 1400 till 1460. Iconclass keywords.value: Public life of Christ (from his baptism until the Passion); story of John the Baptist.

Images descriptions.value: The bust of Christ with praying hands and traces of a garment is depicted. Water is poured onto Him from a jug, hold by a hand in the upper right corner. The Holy Ghost as dove descends from the upper left corner.

Production technique and style.value: Leaded panels made of colourless, bulk coloured and flashed glass, painted with grisaille. Luís Alemão's painting style.

Building.value: Mosteiro de Santa Maria da Vitória (Batalha Monastery)

Current state of conservation.value: 1996: The panel was taken down and paint was prefixed (Paraloid B72 in butyl acetate [5%]). Biocidal treatment (folmaldehyde aqueous solution [0,1%]) and superficial cleaning (distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs) were carried out. Due to general structural failure, the panel was dismantled, cleaned and releaded. Repair lead calms were removed and the glass fragments were bound using Araldite 2020. Small gaps were filled in using Araldite 2020; bigger ones were filled in with cold painted colourless glass (with acrylic paints Pébeo). The upper part of the garment, made up of 8 glass fragments, was very thin and fragile, and had to be backplated. The plating used thin laboratory borosilicate glass, conformed to the outer surface of the original glass in the kiln. It was peripherally isolated using copperfoil. In the course of releading, grey transparent glass was introduced as a replacement for gaps filled in with lead and putty in the 19th century restoration. Tinted glazier's putty was locally applied in order to streghten the panel. The panel was kept in storage. Conservator: Ana Paula de Melo Barroso.                              2012: The panel was put on display at the Batalha Monastery's interpretation centre, inside a climatized showcase (RH 60%, 18 °C).

Description.value: St. John the Baptist stands against a background made up of a deep blue sky and green countryside landscape, including schematic pine trees and smaller plants. The saint wears the current camel hair garment. This depiction is directly related to the one under the same title and the inventory number MB 496.

Description.value: Wearing the Resurrection mantle and holding the Resurrection banner, the risen Christ holds Adam by the wrist, who kneels next to Eve and other damned, over the broken doors of the Underworld, to the detriment of devils, that either agonize or fly away.

Description.value: The Virgin Mary lies in her deathbed, looking up and with her hands in prayer. Her veiled and haloed head rests on two pillows and her arms and body are covered with a sheet and a green bedspread. The bed is depicted as being made of light coloured wood and the background as a deep blue fabric.

Current state of conservation.value: 2006-2007: All the panels were taken down, flattened, and cleaned (distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs). Grisaille painting was pre-fixed and fixed where necessary (Paraloid B72 in acetone [8%]). Glass fragments were bound with Paraloid B72 in acetone (60%)and small gaps filled in with fired painted glass, Iron tie bars directly soldered onto the panel were unsoldered and removed, and copper ties soldered instead. Tinted glazier's putty was locally applied in order to streghten the panel. Reinstalled using new brass tie bars, lime-based mortar (sides and bottom) and glazier's putty (top, along saddle bar above). Isothermal protection. Company: IN SITU. Conservator: Raquel Fonseca dos Santos.

Description.value: An angel, his right knee on the floor, dressing like a valet (see the feathered hat laid on the ground), holds a banner with the Order of Christ's Cross against an ellaborately decorated background. The bottom left part of this decoration includes a piece of glass with the coat of arms of the Dominicans and the date 1514.

Description.value: Christ raises the eucharistic cup with His left hand while pointing downwards with the right one. He wears a deep blue-violet mantle and is frontally depicted against a red background decorated with a yellow pattern made up of the Flagelation whips and pomegrenates.

Description.value: St. John the Evangelist is shown sitting, in a three-quarter views, his right hand laying on the table and holding apparently a piece of bread. In the background, also on thetable, a footed bowl is to be seen. Most of the background pieces, depicting architectural and decorative elements, must have belonged to the same panel but are no longer in their original position.

Grisaille painting was pre-fixed and fixed where necessary (Paraloid B72 in acetone [8%]). Glass fragments were bound with Paraloid B72 in acetone (60%)and small gaps filled in with fired painted glass, Iron tie bars directly soldered onto the panel were unsoldered and removed, and copper ties soldered instead. Description.value: The Virgin Mary sits on a Renaissance throne made of different stone varieties and holds the Christ Child on her lap. The throne is covered by a rich textile canopy bearing the inscription 'SALVE REGINA CELORVM OMNIUM'. Two flying angels crown Mary. Above them, hanging from the canopy, an urn bears the Latin monograms of Jesus and Mary.

Current state of conservation.value: 2002-2003: Panel I1 was taken down, flattened, and cleaned (distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs). Grisaille painting was pre-fixed and fixed where necessary using Paraloid B72 in acetone (8%). Glass fragments were bound with Paraloid B72 in acetone (60%). Iron tie bars directly soldered on to the panel were unsoldered and removed, and copper ties soldered instead. Tinted glazier's putty was locally applied in order to streghten and waterproof the panel. The panel reinstalled using new brass tie bars, lime-based mortar (sides and bottom) and glazier's putty (top, along saddle bar above). Company: IN SITU. Conservator: Clarisse Duarte da Silva.

Description.value: The Virgin Mary stands on a crescent and is surrounded by a rosary, holding the Christ Child in her left arm and a white rose in the right hand. The Christ Child Himself raises a rosary in his right hand. A fortress in the base stands for Mary's virtues.

Production technique and style.value: Leaded panels made of colourless, bulk coloured and flashed glass, painted with grisaille and silver stain. Painting style of the Batalha Monastery chancel window depicting the Annunciation.

Building.value: Mosteiro de Santa Maria da Vitória (Batalha Monastery)

Current state of conservation.value: 2006-2007: External protection grids were removed, deoxidized, protected and painted. All the panels were taken down, flattened, and cleaned (distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs). Grisaille painting was pre-fixed and fixed where necessary (Paraloid B72 in acetone [8%]). Glass fragments were bound with Paraloid B72 in acetone (60%)and small gaps filled in with fired painted glass, Iron tie bars directly soldered onto the panel were unsoldered and removed, and copper ties soldered instead. Tinted glazier's putty was locally applied in order to streghten and waterproof the panel. Reinstalled using new brass tie bars, lime-based mortar (sides and bottom) and glazier's putty (top, along saddle bar above). External protection grids were reinstalled. Company: IN SITU. Conservator: Raquel Fonseca dos Santos.

Description.value: Three successive moments of the Passion of Jesus are depicted in each of the three lancets. From left to right: Jesus being nailed to the Cross; Jesus on the Cross; descent from the Cross. The conserved 16th century tracery panels bear the Arma Christi, heraldry of King Manuel I and of the Dominicans, as well as the date of 1514.

Dcterms:extent.value: Each lancet: h. 350 cm x b. 85 cm; tracery: h. 260 cm x w. 290 cm.

Iconclass keywords.value: The crucifixion of Christ:prelude to Christ's death on the cross / The crucifixion of Christ: Christ's death on the cross; Golgotha / Christ is laid down - descent from the cross / Arma Christi / coat of arms (as symbol of the State

Images descriptions.value: Three successive moments of the Passion of Jesus are depicted in each of the three lancets. From left to right: Jesus being nailed to the Cross; Jesus on the Cross; descent from the Cross. The conserved 16th century tracery panels bear the Arma Christi, heraldry of King Manuel I and of the Dominicans, as well as the date of 1514.

Building.value: Mosteiro de Santa Maria da Vitória (Batalha Monastery)

Current state of conservation.value: 1996: The panel was taken down and kept in storage.                                                                      2009-2010: Superficial cleaning was carried out, using distilled water and ethyl alcohol [50:50] on cotton wool swabs. Paint was locally consolidated with Plexigum N80 in acetone [8%]. Repair lead calms were removed and the glass fragments were bound using Paraloid B72 in acetone [70%]. Some lead calms in the  bottom of the panel were replaced due to structural instability and two peripheral lead calm gaps were filled in. Peripheral U-shaped lead-antimony (98:2) calms were applied and locally soldered to the panel. Some solder points were reinforced and lead calm cracks were soldered.The panel was kept in storage. Conservator: Pedro Redol.                                2012: The panel was put on display at the Batalha Monastery's interpretation centre, inside a climatized showcase (RH 60%, 18 °C).

Description.value: A prophet raises both hands and holds an open scroll in the left one.

REDOL, Pedro - O Mosteiro da Batalha e o vitral em Portugal nos séculos XV e XVI. Batalha: Câmara Municipal da Batalha, 2003.

Images descriptions.value: A prophet raises both hands and holds an open scroll in the left one.

Production technique and style.value: Leaded panels made of colourless, bulk coloured and flashed glass, painted with grisaille. Luís Alemão's painting style.

Building.value: Mosteiro de Santa Maria da Vitória (Batalha Monastery)

Description.value: St. Anthony the Abbot is depicted in the foreground, wearing a mantle with an embroidered tau-shaped cross and surroudend by devils. A pig with a bell and an open book showing an excerpt of the Gloria Patri lie at the saint's feet. Above, in the background, a sactuary and the St. Anthony in a dominican habit, seized and dragged through the air by devils, are to be seen.

also called the Great; attributes: bell

A pig with a bell and an open book showing an excerpt of the Gloria Patri lie at the saint's feet. Above, in the background, a sactuary and the St. Anthony in a dominican habit, seized and dragged through the air by devils, are to be seen.

Photographic process.value: Transmitted light, inverted back single shot
